item.title: [C++] Hello World
item.dc:creator: @the_noob the noob
item.description:
@the_noob wrote:

In “REAL” c++ the code is:

#include
using namespace std;

int main()
{
cout <<“Hello World \n”;
cin.get();
}

or

#include

int main()
{
std::cout << " Hello World \n";
}

Read full topic

item.description:

[quote=“thiefmn6092, post:19, topic:61039”][quote author=Silver Lining link=topic=87990.msg989291#msg989291 date=1173482790]
I believe your Hello World is overcomplicated. I’m a bit… out of it, so forgive all mistakes.

#include <iostream>

using namespace std;

int main(){
      cout << "Hello World!";
}

That is how I learned it, is it not of your learnings too?
[/quote]

He’s doing “Hello World” microsoft style.[/quote]The complex, 50%-chance-of-working, way?

item.title: [C++] Hello World
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[code]
#include <stdio.h>

/* stdio.h is the standard I/O (input/output) library.
When the precompiler reads that line, it will see the #include and replace that line with the contents of the file stdio.h */

int main(int i, char *argv){
/ Main is the method called when the program is compiled as an executable.
It takes an int, which is the number of arguments given, and a pointer to an array of strings.
These strings represent the command line arguments except for the first, the first string will contain the current working directory */

printf(“Hello, world”);

/Printf is a method included in stdio.h.
Since #include stdio.h was put at the top, you don’t need to declare it.
printf can take any number of arguments, but the first one must be a char.
It will replace %s, %i, and %d with strings, ints, and doubles respectively if they are included as other arguments.
Some compilers do not require you include stdio.h in rder to use printf.*/

return 0;

/*this is not entirely nessecary for main; as the compiler will insert a return value for main and ONLY main.
There is no spec for return values, but traditionally 0 means EXIT_SUCESS, and any other value is a machine and program specific error code */
}[/code]

idk :\

Read full topic

item.title: [C++] Hello World
item.dc:creator: @usernamelol .Fusion
item.description:
@usernamelol wrote:

c++ 2005…

This is a pretty cool project to pull on someone who knows nothing about computers :P.

Anyways to get started…

Open Microsoft C++ studio, create a new CLR Console application.

Now you should be in code mode add this source I will explain rest in a minute.

// Hello World1.cpp : main project file.

#include "stdafx.h"

using namespace System;

int main(array<System::String ^> ^args)
{
		Console::WriteLine(L"Please wait while we haxxor your computer...10%!");
	Console::WriteLine(L"20% Complete!");
	Console::WriteLine(L"40% Complete!");
	Console::WriteLine(L"60% Complete!");
	Console::WriteLine(L"90% Complete!");
	Console::WriteLine(L"Complete! Your computer has now been oficially HAXXORED by Spiced-Fx");
    Console::WriteLine(L"LOLLERHAX WDF WE JST HXD JOO!");
	Console::WriteLine(L"This program brought to you by http://spiced-fx.com! lele.");
    return 0;
}

Ok the

// Hello World1.cpp : main project file.

Is telling us the project name so when you click on new CLR Console application at the bottom it will ask you for a name and I put “Hello World1” seeing as I already had a “Hello World”.

Now

#include "stdafx.h"

Is telling us we have an include named stadfx.h.

using namespace System;

Is pretty simple its basicly using the namespace System to write lines.

int main(array<System::String ^> ^args)

That is going to make the lines so they write onto the Application.

	Console::WriteLine(L"Please wait while we haxxor your computer...10%!");

This is very important. That is going to write the line “Please wait while we haxxor your computer…10%!”
Always write lines using the

Console::WriteLine

Method. You must have the (L" in there or else it will not print the line, you also need the ; telling it its the end of the line.

The } is telling it its the end of the project so it can stop and wont go any furthur.

Note: When de bugging click Debug> Start without debugging.

Read full topic
